ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Medical software design!
What goes into creating medical software, different case studies where things went wrong, how to write a software requirements document, design document, and validation plan.
An introduction overview to software medical device regulation and production into the mainstream market.

I learned about the biomedical device development process, which includes system requirements, software design, and a validation plan. I also learned about several failed products or software that were usually developed for non-technical purposes (healthcare, election apps, etc.).
The entire process of the ideation, creation, and validation of a medical software.

SO MANY!! Prof P is very knowledgeable in the medical devices and regulation field and has plenty of stories and anecdotes to share. From regulation to team-skills, I really appreciated taking this course my last semester
Medical Software Design, including things such as privacy matters, history, and important mishaps and how to prevent them.

I gained a broad understanding of the complexities involved in designing medical software and the regulatory framework that governs it. This course provided a thorough overview of the entire medical software development process, from initial design to final implementation. 

One of the most valuable aspects of the course was the emphasis on regulatory compliance. We learned about the various regulatory bodies that oversee medical software development, such as the FDA, and the specific requirements that must be met in order to gain approval for a product.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Xenophon is quite possibly the coolest Professor ever! Love him!

Professor Papademetris is a wonderful instructor and cares deeply about the students and facilitating learning. You get to work hands on with the project throughout the semester and have access to mentors that are doing meaningful research.

Being able to work closely with a mentor and draft the documents you would need to develop actual medical software provides a lot of useful practical experience. You get to think about product design and also have the opportunity to practice writing clear and concise documents. Lectures were also very structured and worked well with the assignments. However, some of the lectures were a bit boring if they covered the regulatory process in detail (but that is simply the nature of the topics). Feedback is also given thoroughly for each assignment!

Strengths: structured lecture, amazing professor and TA (shoutout Anja), great speakers, cool projects!
Weakness: none!
The structure of the class was very clear and manageable. Prof P understands the student life and works super hard to accommodate for us

This course covers an important aspect of medical software design that is often overlooked - regulation. However, the teaching style may not be the most memorable. The majority of the course is delivered through lectures, which can feel like a checkbox exercise rather than a hands-on design experience. As you work on assignments, you may feel like you are simply ticking off boxes rather than creating a comprehensive design document.

This course is an ideal class for seniors due to its extremely chill and relaxed atmosphere and generous pacing. One of its core strengths is the relaxed environment, which allows students to learn at their own pace without feeling overwhelmed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Prof. Papademetris is incredibly nice, cool, and facilitates learning well! I loved the class.

Yes, I would take this class if you are interested in medical software design at a high level. The semester long project can be as programming intensive as you want it to be, but overall, it is very manageable and the workload mostly comes from writing and brainstorming assignments.
Yes. It was an amazing opportunity to crossover the BME and CS worlds. The work was very manageable and the teaching was fun and relaxed. Overall it was one of the best electives I've taken at Yale.

Yes! If you're interested in how medical devices and software get developed, I think it's a great course. While there's not much programming, it's also just as important to practice writing and thinking about system design.
Yes yes yes! Take it and you will love it.
YES! I really enjoyed the team experience and getting to see real-time how the lectures fit with the work we were doing on our project.
Absolutely. You get to tour really cool medical facilities, meet amazing professors/medical experts, and involve yourself with the med school.

I would recommend this course if a student is looking for a very chill class or gut. However, if you're looking for a course that focuses heavily on coding, this may not be the best fit for you as there isn't a significant amount of coding involved.
